newsitem.title: USA: Sara Lee prepares for orderly transition.
newsitem.headline: Sara Lee prepares for orderly transition.

text.p: Sara Lee Corp, which named a president and vice chairman Thursday, is laying the groundwork for a successor to Chairman John Bryan, analysts said.

The food and consumer products company appointed C. Steven McMillan to the post of president and Donald Franceschini as vice chairman in a move the company said would begin an orderly management transition for the short and long terms.
"They've been right below Bryan for some time now, and they've both done incredible jobs for Sara Lee," Sally Schaadt, an analyst at Fourteen Research, said.
Several industry analysts praised the jobs McMillan and Franceschini have done in the food and personal products operations, respectively.
"Both have good track records and both are held in high regard," Ellen Baras, an analyst at Nesbitt Burns, said.

"McMillan is clearly being tested," she added. "Looking at the two of them, McMillan is age-appropriate for the appointment (to eventually succeed Bryan). He'll also be involved in all aspects of Sara Lee's businesses," Baras said.
William Leach, an analyst at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, also believes McMillan is likely to succeed Bryan.
"McMillan is a good executive. John Bryan is 60 years old, and he's not going to live forever," Leach said.
John McMillin, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said he was not surprised at all by McMillan's appointment.
"The question for me was not whether Steve McMillan would be named president, but when he would be named president," he said.
"He's done a wonderful job developing Sara Lee's food business, and he's had experience working with some of the products," McMillin said.
Sara Lee shares were off 1/8 at 42-3/4 in late trading on Thursday.
